lesson.name: Lesson 1.7 Explaining Steps for Rewriting Equations

page.title: 1.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will further develop the idea of equivalent equations by applying the concept of acceptable moves. Additionally, you will encounter equations that have no solutions with moves that appear to be acceptable. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain why some algebraic moves create equivalent equations but some do not.
  • Describe how equivalent equations are related to the steps of solving equations.
  • Explain what it means for an equation to have no solutions and recognize such an equation.
Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:
  • 1.7.1: Determining if Zero Is a Solution 
  • 1.7.2: Explaining Acceptable Moves Used to Solve an Equation 
  • 1.7.2: Self Check 
  • 1.7.3: Understanding Equations with No Solution or Infinitely Many
  • 1.7.3: Self Check 
  • 1.7.4: Solving Equations by Dividing Values 
After that, you’ll practice and review.
  • 1.7.5: Practice
  • 1.7.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.7.1: Determining if Zero Is a Solution
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity 

Choose the equations where 0 is a solution of an equation. 

a. \( 4(x + 2) = 10 \)


b. \( 12 - 8x = 3(x + 4) \)


c. \( 5x = \frac12 x \)


d. \( \frac {6}{x} + 1 = 8 \)


Enter your answer in the textbox.

Answers include B and C

Check your reasoning against these sample responses:

a. No. Sample reasoning: If \( x=0 \), then the expression on the left has the value 8, which makes the equation false.

b. Yes. Sample reasoning: Substituting 0 for \( x \) gives \( 12=12 \), which is true.

c. Yes. Sample reasoning: 5 multiplied by 0 is 0, and \( \frac{1}{2} \) multiplied by 0 is also 0, so the two sides of the equation are equal.

d. No. Sample reasoning: Dividing by 0 gives an undefined result, so it cannot be added by 1 to equal 8.

page.title: 1.7.2: Explaining Acceptable Moves to Solve an Equation
page.contents:
Activity

Here are some pairs of equations. While one partner listens, the other partner should:

  • Choose a pair of equations from column A. Explain why, if \( x \) is a number that makes the first equation true, then it also makes the second equation true.
  • Choose a pair of equations from column B. Explain why the second equation is no longer true for a value of \( x \) that makes the first equation true.

Then, switch roles until you run out of time or you run out of pairs of equations.

Some principles you might use to complete this activity include the following:

  • Distributive Property
  • Addition Property of Equality
  • Additive Inverse
  • Subtraction Property of Equality
  • Multiplication Property of Equality
  • Division Property of Equality

A B
1. \( 16=4(9-x) \)
\( 16=36-4x \)		 \( 9x = 5x + 4 \)
\( 14x = 4 \)
2. \( 5x = 24 + 2x \)
\( 3x = 24 \)		 \( \frac12x - 8 = 9 \)
\( x - 8 = 18 \)
3. \( -3(2x +9)=12 \)
\( 2x+9=-4 \)		 \( 6x - 6 = 3x \)
\( x - 1 = 3x \)
4. \( 5x=3-x \)
\( 5x = -x + 3 \)		 \( -11(x -2) = 8 \)
\( x-2 = 8 + 11 \)
5. \( 18 = 3x - 6 + x \)
\( 18 = 4x - 6 \)		 \( 4 - 5x = 24 \)
\( 5x = 20 \)

After you have discussed these equations with your partner, select the Sample Responses button to check your reasoning.


Here is how to check the solution to the equation in two variables.

Check your reasoning for the equations you discussed.
 
Column A: Sample response:
  1. By the distributive property, \( 4(9−x) \) is equal to \( 36−4x \) for any value of \( x\). If \( 4(9−x) \) is equal to \(16\), then \( 36−4x \) is also equal to \(16\).
  2. If the two sides of the equation are equal, then they are still equal if the same amount, in this case \( 2x \), is subtracted from each side. 
  3. \( -3(2x+9) \) divided by \( -3\) is \( 2x+9 \) and \( 12 \) divided by -\( 3 \) is \( -4 \). Because \( -3(2x+9) \) is equal to \( 12 \), dividing each of them by \(  -3 \) gives the same result, so it is true that \( 2x+9 \) is equal \( −4 \).
  4. Subtracting by a number is equivalent to adding its opposite, so \( 3−x \) is equivalent to \( 3+-x \). Changing the order in which we add two numbers doesn't change the sum, per commutative property of addition. If \( 5x \) is equal to \( 3+-x \), then it is also equal to \( -x+3 \).
  5. Using the commutative property, \( 3x−6+x \) can be rewritten as \( 3x+x−6 \). Combining like terms gives an equivalent expression, \( 4x−6 \), so \( 4x−6 \) is also equal to \( 18 \).
Column B: Sample response:
  1. If the expressions \( 9x \) and \( 5x+4 \) are equal, then adding \( 5x \) to one expression and subtracting \( 5x \) from the other make the two expressions unequal.
  2. The 9 on the right side of the equation is multiplied by 2. If the expression on the left side was also multiplied by 2, the two sides would stay equal, but only a part of the expression on the left is doubled, so the two sides of the equation are no longer equal.
  3. If two expressions are equal, dividing one side by 6 but not dividing the other side by 6 makes them unequal.
  4. The left side of the first equation is divided by \( -11 \) but the right side is being added by 11. Performing two different operations with different numbers on the same value may not keep an equation true.
  5. Subtracting 4 from two values that are equal keeps the equation true. The expression on the left was multiplied (or divided) by \( -1 \), however, the expression on the right was not, so the two expressions are no longer equal.

page.title: 1.7.2: Self Check
page.contents: Select all of the following equations that are equivalent to \( 3(x - 2) = 18 \).

answer.response: That's correct! Check yourself: Both sides were correctly divided by 3. This equation is equivalent to \( 3(x - 2) = 18 \).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The 3 should have been distributed to both x and the -2. The answers are \( x - 2 = 6 \), \( 3x - 6 = 18 \), and \( 3x = 24 \).
That's correct! Check yourself: The 3 was correctly distributed on the left side of the equation. This equation is equivalent to \( 3(x-2)=18 \).
That's correct! Check yourself: After distribution, the 6 was correctly added to both sides. This equation is equivalent to \( 3(x-2)=18 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.7.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Equations Without Solutions

What happens when we solve \( 5z = 5z - 1\)?

Subtract \(5z\) to get the \(z\) terms together on one side.

\( 5z-5z = 5z-5z - 1 \)

Simplify—the \(z\) terms are gone!

\( 0 \neq 1 \)

 
Since 0 does not equal \(-1\), this equation led to a false statement. There are no solutions to this equation.

Example:

Solve \( 5m+3(9+3m)=2(7m−11) \). 

Original equation

\(5m+3(9+3m)=2(7m−11)\)

Distribute

\(5m +27+9m =14m-22\)

Combine like terms

\(14m +27 =14m -22\)

Subtract \(14m\) from both sides so the \(m\) terms are together.

\(14m -14m +27 =14m -14m-22\)

Simplify. (The \(m\) terms are gone!)

\(27=-22\)

The equation \(27 = -22\) is NOT a true statement. The equation \(5m+3(9+3m)=2(7m−11)\) has no solutions.

Try It: Equations Without Solutions 

Solve \( 3x - 4 = 3(x -2) \) and determine the number of solutions..

Write down your answer, then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve this linear equation and determine the number of solutions:
Original equation  \( 3x - 4 = 3(x -2) \)
Distribute  \( 3x - 4 = 3x -6 \)
Subtract \( 10x \) from each side so the \( x \)’s are together. \( 3x-3x - 4 = 3x -3x-6 \)
Simplify-the x’s are gone!  \( -4 = -6 \)

The final step, \( -4 = -6 \) is NOT a true statement so the equation \( 3x - 4 = 3(x -2) \) has no solution.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!


Infinitely Many Solutions

What if an equation results in a true statement without variables?

The equations \( -4 = -4 \), \( 5 = 5 \), and \( 0 = 0 \) are all true statements because one side is equal to the other. This means that any value of the variable in the original equation would be a solution. When this happens in the final step of an equation, there are infinitely many solutions.

Example: Solve \( 2y +6 =2(y+3) \)

Distribute.

\( 2y+6 = 2y +6 \)

Subtract 2y to bring y's to one side.

\( 2y-2y+6 = 2y-2y +6 \)
Simplify - the y's are gone! \( 6 = 6 \)

 

We say the solution to the equation is all of the real numbers. An equation that is true for any value of the variable like this is called an identity.

An equation that is true for any value of the variable is called an identity.

The solution of an identity is all real numbers.


Try It: Equations Without Solutions 

Solve \( 10x - 4 = 2(5x -2) \) and determine the number of solutions..

Write down your answer, then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to solve this linear equation using a general strategy:
Original equation  \( 10x - 4 = 2(5x -2) \)
Distribute  \( 10x - 4 =10x - 4 \)
Subtract \( 10x \) from each side so the \( x \)’s are together.  \( 10x-10x - 4 =10x - 10x - 4 \)
Simplify-the x’s are gone!  \( -4 = -4 \)


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I'd like to retry the self check
I'm ready for the next activity

page.title: 1.7.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Video: Acceptable Moves

Watch the following video to learn more about acceptable moves. 

Solving Equations and Creating Equivalent Equations

One way to create equivalent equations is to solve the equation. In each step of solving, an equivalent equation is created.

Here is a general strategy for solving linear equations:

Step 1

Simplify each side of the equation as much as possible.

  • Use the Distributive Property to remove any parentheses.
  • Combine like terms.

Step 2

Collect all the variable terms on one side of the equation.

  • Use the Addition or Subtraction Property of Equality.

Step 3

Collect all the constant terms on the other side of the equation.

  • Use the Addition or Subtraction Property of Equality.

Step 4 

Make the coefficient of the variable term equal to 1.

  • Use the Multiplication or Division Property of Equality.
  • State the solution to the equation.

Step 5

Check the solution. 

  • Substitute the solution into the original equation to make sure the result is a true statement.


Here is an example of solving equations. Notice that each step is an acceptable move that creates an equivalent equation. 


Summary:
Ways to create an equivalent equation:
  • Solve an equation.
    • Use properties of equality.
  • Use the Distributive Property.
  • Simplify.
  • Combine like terms.

Try It: Solving Equations and Creating Equivalent Equations

Write two equivalent equations to \( 2(x+4)= 12 \).

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.


Here are some possible ways to find equivalent equations to \( 3x + 5 = 15 \):

Step 1

Simplify each side of the equation as much as possible.

  • Use the Distributive Property to remove any parentheses.
  • Combine like terms.

\( 2(x+4)= 12 \)

\( 2x +8 =12 \)

Step 2

Collect all the variable terms on one side of the equation.

  • Use the Addition or Subtraction Property of Equality.

\( 2x +8 =12 \)

Step 3

Collect all the constant terms on the other side of the equation.

  • Use the Addition or Subtraction Property of Equality.

 \( 2x +8 =12 \)

 \( -8 \)    \( -8 \)

\( 2x = 4 \)

Step 4 

Make the coefficient of the variable term equal to 1.

  • Use the Multiplication or Division Property of Equality.
  • State the solution to the equation.

 \( 2x = 4 \)

\( 2 \frac{x}{2} = \frac{4}{2} \)

\( x=2 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I'd like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.7.3: Equations with No Solution or Infinitely Many
page.contents:
Activity

Noah is having trouble solving two equations. In each case, he took steps that he thought were acceptable but ended up with statements that are clearly not true.

Analyze Noah’s work on each equation and the moves he made. Were they acceptable moves? Why do you think he ended up with a false equation?

Discuss your observations with your group and be prepared to share your conclusions. If you get stuck, consider solving each equation.

Example 1

Original equation.

\( x+6 =4x+1-3x \)

Apply the Commutative Property.

\( x+6 =4x-3x+1 \)

Combine like terms.

\( x+6 =x+1 \)

Subtract \(x\) from each side.

\( 6 =1 \)

 

Example 2

Original equation.

\( 2(5+x)-1=3x+9 \)

Apply the Distributive Property.

\( 10+2x-1 =3x+9 \)

Subtract 10 from each side.

 \( 2x-1 =3x-1 \)        

Add 1 to each side.

\( 2x=3x \)

Divide each side by \(x\).

\( 2= 3 \)


Why did Noah have no solution for either equation? Enter your answer in the textbox.

What did you consider?  Here are other possible responses. 


Example 1: All the moves that Noah made were acceptable, but because he ended up with a false statement, that means there is no value of \( x \) that makes the first equation true. We can see it in the third line: \( x + 6 = x + 1 \). There is no number that can make the equation true.


Example 2: Noah's moves seem acceptable except for the last one. If he had subtracted \( 2x \) from each side of the equation, he would have \( 0 = x \). Instead, he divided both sides by \( x \) which would give an undefined number if \( x\;\;is\;\;0 \). 


Noah tried to solve a third equation and ended up with a true statement, without variables.

Example 3:


original equation

\( 2 (4 + x) - 2 = 2x + 6 \)

Apply the distributive property.

\( 8+ 2x - 2 =2x + 6 \)

Combine Like Terms

\( 2x +6 = 2x +6 \)

Subtract 6 from both sides.

\( 2x = 2x \)

Subtract 2x from both sides.

\( 0=0 \)

 

Since there is not a variable and the statement is true, any value of x would be a solution for the original equation. So, this equation has infinitely many solutions.


Extend Your Thinking

1. We can't divide the number 100 by zero because dividing by zero is undefined.

a. Instead, try dividing 100 by 10, then 1, then 0.1, then 0.01. What do you notice happens as you divide by smaller numbers?

10, 100, 1000, 10,000. Sample response: The quotients are getting very large.


b. Now try dividing the number -100 by 10, by 1, by 0.1, 0.01. What is the same and what is different?

-10, -100, -1000, -10,000. Sample response: The absolute values of the quotients are the same, but the sign is opposite..


2. In middle school, you used tape diagrams to represent division. This tape diagram shows that 6÷2=3



a. Draw a tape diagram that shows why 6\div\frac{1}{2}=12. After you have drawn your answer, select the Solution button to check your work.


b. Try to draw a tape diagram that represents 6÷0. Explain why this is so difficult.

Sample response: The zero takes up no space, so no matter how many copies we have it could never reach 6.

page.title: 1.7.4: Solving Equations by Dividing Values
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

1. The equation \( 4(x-2) = 100 \) is a true equation for a particular value of \( x \). Explain why \( 2(x-2) = 50 \) is also true for the same value of \( x \). 
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:
If \( 4(x−2) \) and 100 are equal, then multiplying \( 4(x−2) \) by \( \frac{1}{2} and multiplying 100 by \( \frac{1}{2}) \) will give two results that are also equal, so \( 2(x−2)=50) \) must be true.


2. To solve the equation \( 7.5d=2.5d \), Lin divides each side by \( 2.5d \), and Elena subtracts \( 2.5d \) from each side.
a. Will both moves lead to the solution? Explain your reasoning.
b. What is the solution?

Enter your answer here:

Check your answers:

a. No. Sample reasoning: Lin's move won't work. Dividing by \( 2.5d \) gives \( 3=1 \), which is not true. Dividing by the variable we are trying to solve makes us think there is no solution. Subtracting \( 2.5d \) from both sides gives \( 5d=0 \).
b. \( d=0 \)

page.title: 1.7.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain why some algebraic moves create equivalent equations but some do not.
  • Illustrate that dividing by a variable is not used in solving equations because it can lead to equations that have fewer solutions than the original equation.
  • Demonstrate that equations that are not true for any value of the variable(s) do not have solutions.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.7.1: Determining if Zero Is a Solution 
    • In this activity, you substituted 0 into equations to determine for which equations 0 was a solution.
  • 1.7.2: Explaining Acceptable Moves Used to Solve an Equation
    • In this activity, you learned how acceptable moves applied to an equation can create an equivalent equation. Through these discussions you had the opportunity to construct logical arguments.
  • 1.7.2: Self Check
  • 1.7.3: Equations with No Solution or Infinitely Many
    • In this activity, you explored why equations may not have a solution and if the moves made to solve the equations were acceptable.
  • 1.7.3: Self Check 
  • 1.7.4: Solving Equations by Dividing Values
    • In this activity, you used division to find equivalent equations and also learned that you can not divide by 0.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.7.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 1.7.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following equations has a solution?

answer.response: Correct. When x is subtracted from each side and each side is divided by 2, \( x \) will have a solution, \( x = 9 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try this another way. There are no values for \( x \) that will make this equation true. The correct answer is \( 3x = x + 18 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try this another way. Subtract \( x \) from both sides results in a false equation, \( 3 = -2 \). There are no values for \( x \) that will make this equation true. The correct answer is \( 3x = x + 18 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try this another way. Combining the like terms on the right side and subtracting \( 10x \) from both sides results in a false statement, \( 10 = 0 \). There are no values for \( x \) that will make this equation true. The correct answer is \( 3x = x + 18 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.7.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

1. Match each equation with an equivalent equation. Some of the answer choices are not used.

  1. \(3x + 6 = 4x + 7\)
  2. \(3 (x + 6) = 4x + 7\)
  3. \(4x + 3x = 7 - 6\)
  1. \(9x = 4x + 7\)
  2. \(3x + 18 = 4x + 7\)
  3. \(3x = 4x + 7\)
  4. \(3x - 1 = 4x\)
  5. \(7x = 1\)

 a.  \(3x + 6 = 4x + 7\)

Correct! \(3x - 1 = 4x\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3x - 1 = 4x. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


b. 3 (x + 6) = 4x + 7

Correct! \(3x + 18 = 4x + 7\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3x + 18 = 4x + 7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


c. \(4x + 3x = 7 - 6\)

Correct! \(3x + 18 = 4x + 7\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(3x + 18 = 4x + 7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. Is 0 a solution to \(2x + 10 = 4x + 10\)?

Correct! 2(0)+10=4(0)=10 so 10=10 and x=0 is a solution.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.7.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Yes, 2(0)+10=4(0)=10 so 10=10 and x=0 is a solution. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


3. Is 0 a solution to 5x + 7 = 0? Explain or show your reasoning.

Correct! 5(0)+7=0 becomes 7=0 so, x=0 is not a solution.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.7.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is No. 5(0)+7=0 becomes 7=0 so, x=0 is not a solution. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4. Which equation is equivalent to 6(x-3)=24?

Correct! x-3=4

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.7.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is x-3=4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


5. Which of the following sets of equations are equivalent to each other?

Correct! 10(x+9) = 50 and 2(x+9)=10. Each side of the equation was divided by 5. So the equations are equivalent.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 10(x+9) = 50 and 2(x+9)=10. Each side of the equation was divided by 5. So the equations are equivalent. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


6. Is 0 a solution to 4x = 9x?

: Correct! 4(0)=9(0) becomes 0=0, so x=0 is a solution to the equation.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.7.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Yes because 4(0)=9(0) becomes 0=0, so x=0 is a solution to the equation. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


7. Using the distributive property, choose which equation would be an equivalent equation to 3(x-2) =7.

Correct! 3x - 6 =7

Try again: Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.7.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 3x - 6 =7. It is one of the solutions that could be equivalent to 3(x-2) =7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
